tweet: Chair Powell reiterated the importance of Fed independence in today's press conference. Soon after that, Trump doubled down on efforts to pressure the Fed. pic.twitter.com/C1idam6MJw
Yellen went on to say she would be inclined to cut "a bit," adding: "I wouldn't see this as the beginning, unless things change, of a major easing cycle."

The #Fed's decision to cut today reflects concerns about persistently low inflation and the global economic slowdown. The latter is partially a result of President Trump’s trade wars, as former Chair Janet Yellen noted earlier this week. Check out the video of her remarks. pic.twitter.com/MshJpghCuU

See why the #Fed went from expecting rate hikes this year to cutting today, in the first reduction since the Great Recession. This from Chair Powell's press conference taking place right now. pic.twitter.com/PxdFWkMunc

That's a cut of 25 basis points. Also, the #Fed in August will stop shrinking its portfolio of assets. Quantitative tightening, as the shrinking program is known, can cause tighter monetary conditions. Today's decision is good news for proponents of looser monetary conditions.

And it's a rate cut! From the statement: "In light of the implications of global developments for the economic outlook as well as muted inflation pressures, the Committee decided to lower the target range for the federal funds rate to 2 to 2-1/4 percent."  https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/monetary20190731a1.pdf …
Stay tuned for the #Fed rate decision in 2 minutes. Markets are expecting the first cut since 2008. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/31/business/economy/fed-meeting-interest-rates.html …
Don't forget there's a #Fed rate decision today at 2:00pm EST, followed by press conference 30 minutes later! https://twitter.com/federalreserve/status/1156549506105847808 …

NEW: Private-sector employment rose by 156K in July, as gains in professional/business services & health care offset tepid growth in manufacturing, @ADP reported. "While we still see strength in the labor market, it has shown signs of weakening,” ADP's @Ahu_Yildirmaz said. pic.twitter.com/5yTPwvAHmP

This week @JECDems will publish Episode 3 of the Economic Explainer Podcast. This one is on the economics of Paid Family Leave with renowned economist @EileenAppelbaum. In the meantime, check out prior episodes on our website! https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/democrats/podcast …

The Administration's aid "provides the means for the largest farms to get even larger," as mid-sized family farms decline, Bloomberg quotes Roger Johnson, president of the National Farmers Union, as saying.

According to research by @ewg based on @USDA data, the top 1% of recipients got on average more than $180K. The bottom 80% averaged less than $5K. https://www.ewg.org/agmag/2019/07/usda-bailout-impact-trump-s-tariffs-goes-biggest-richest-farmers …

Trump Administration payments to help farmers hit by the trade war have disproportionately benefited bigger & wealthier farmers. The payment system favors the largest producers, and includes a loophole that allows corporations to exceed caps on payments. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-30/majority-of-trump-s-trade-aid-went-to-biggest-farms-study-finds …

In fact, the Medicaid expansion has had the most positive impact among rural populations. The rate of uninsured people fell from 35% to 16% in rural areas and small towns in states that expanded Medicaid.  https://ccf.georgetown.edu/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/FINALHealthInsuranceCoverage_Rural_2018.pdf …

Former President Johnson signed Medicare & Medicaid into law 54 years ago today. In addition to providing tens of millions with access to health care, these programs have helped grow state economies. The Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act gave an additional boost. pic.twitter.com/RegR5cObWQ

Meanwhile, Black and Hispanic homeownershp rates haven’t returned to pre-recession levels and fell in Q2. In many cases high starter-home prices offset historically low mortgage rates. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-25/black-homeownership-falls-to-record-low-as-affordability-worsens …

There's still a big racial homeownership divide in America, with Black and Hispanic rates well below those of white people, according to @uscensusbureau data. One reason, according to @washingtonpost, is people of color often face higher fees on loans.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/the-black-white-employment-gap-has-closed-but-the-homeownership-gap-has-not-heres-why/2018/07/06/1c6943dc-7ef6-11e8-b0ef-fffcabeff946_story.html?utm_term=.653bb0d0efc8 … pic.twitter.com/uIMExic3dR

ICYMI: @JECDems published a fact sheet on the federal #minimumwage this month showing $7.25/hr isn't nearly enough to make ends meet. "Taxpayers end up picking up much of the cost of the shortfall between the minimum wage and a living wage..."  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/8ffcf27c-e08b-4936-9d71-1a1fa98e3675/federal-minimum-wage.pdf … https://twitter.com/nowthisnews/status/1155682609277521920 …

Fascinating IMF report shows the $100 bill has overtaken the $1 bill in circulation volume for the 1st time ever. Why? Most $100 bills are held overseas, meaning geopolitical instability could be driving the trend.  https://blogs.imf.org/2019/07/25/us100-bill-on-the-rise/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery … pic.twitter.com/sdZSh31CpE

Trump claimed GDP growth would hit 3% last yr. But revised data Fri show GDP grew only 2.5% in Q4 from the same quarter in 2017. "While one quarterly GDP reading doesn’t constitute a trend, it’s worth remembering that the Congressional Budget Office, Federal Reserve and International Monetary Fund all forecast growth will start slowing this year."

Some other revealing #'s in today's Q2 GDP report: Net exports fell 5.2% amid the global economic slowdown. And government spending surged 5%.

Revisions in today's GDP report show the economy expanded 2.5% last year (on a Q4-over-Q4 basis), far short of the administration's 3%+ target. https://twitter.com/BChappatta/status/1154734810692292609 …

* Gross private domestic investment fell 5.5% after 6.2% growth pic.twitter.com/2DFeSDPBnJ

SOME USEFUL FACTS: Trump inherited a growing economy and stock market, falling unemployment and low inflation. The # of people working has hit a record nearly every month since May 2014. The Dow surpassed its all-time high 4 years before Trump took office. pic.twitter.com/KIUclGfHWr
(3/3) And already half of all Americans are at risk of not maintaining their living standards in retirement. pic.twitter.com/dlaJysgprz

(2/3) If those pensions run out, that would be devastating to workers who paid into the plans for years. That will add to the growing retirement problem, where it’s becoming harder for many to save for retirement. Meanwhile, fewer and fewer employers offer retirement plans. pic.twitter.com/dgWOQXB5Oz

THREAD (1/3) More than a million workers & retirees are at risk of losing their multiemployer pension plans, which are retirement accounts maintained by more than 1 employer. And the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., which insures such plans, is running out of funds.

Housing data was mixed this week. Sales of existing homes fell 1.7% in June from May, @nardotrealtor reported, while sales of new single-family homes rose 7%, according to @uscensusbureau & @HUDgov. All this against a backdrop of falling mortgage rates in recent months. pic.twitter.com/EniEeBPFDQ

NEW: The @IHSMarkitPMI output index inched up in July. Gains in the services sector offset a drop in manufacturing, which fell to the lowest level since 2009. “Data indicated that the economy started the third quarter on a disappointingly soft footing,” @WilliamsonChris said. pic.twitter.com/o0fopQ1oFb

(3/3) Tax cuts to the top 1% of taxpayers received in the 2017 GOP tax law cost more than the entire SNAP program. Meanwhile the cost of SNAP is falling. According to @CenterOnBudget, “as currently structured, SNAP is not contributing to long-term budgetary pressures.” pic.twitter.com/0gzGkw6CPX

(2/3) A little-known fact about programs like SNAP is that they can soften the impact of recessions by enabling recipients to keep spending on necessities, slowing a drop in aggregate demand. pic.twitter.com/IP43wMJxEZ

THREAD (1/3) Cutting SNAP is bad economics. Studies show SNAP recipients have improved rates of high school graduation and employment, as well as better earnings. That’s a win for everyone, including the U.S. economy. https://twitter.com/GreensteinCBPP/status/1153740238289866756 …

"A common misperception is that the minimum wage is earned primarily by teenagers. But this simply isn’t true." (6/6) During negotiations for a new contact that took effect in 2017, U.S. Soccer rejected requests to pay the women at least the same as the men. #EqualPay
(5/6) Playing conditions for women were worse. For years, 1-in-5 domestic games were on artificial surfaces, which can cause injury. Only 2% of men’s games were on fake turf in the same period.
(4/6) In 2014, the men received bonuses of nearly $5.4M for losing in the Round of 16. Women in 2015 earned $1.7M for winning the tournament.
(3/6) The lawsuit alleges other injustices. In 2013-2016, women earned $15,000 for making the #WorldCup team; men earned at least $55,000.

(2/6) For example, for years women were paid a maximum $99,000 a year for 20 non-tournament games, while men received an average of $263,000. That means that, all else held equal, women were paid 38 cents on the dollar compared to men.

THREAD (1/6): The #USWNT deserves massive congratulations for its victory, but players also deserve to be compensated accordingly. Their lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation reveals huge inequalities.  https://int.nyt.com/data/documenthelper/653-us-womens-soccer-complaint/f9367608e2eaf10873f4/optimized/full.pdf#page=1 … pic.twitter.com/sEh3EBQdio

55 years after the passage of the Civil Rights Act, black children experience far less upward mobility than white children. For every 100 black children who grow up in households in the bottom 5th of the income distribution, less than 3 will make it to the top 5th as adults.
In 2017, poverty rates among black people were 21%—more than twice as high as the white poverty rate of less than 9%.
Disparities persist in household wealth. The homeownership rate for black families was 41% in Q1 and 73% for white families. pic.twitter.com/pERZY8lOej

Disparities persist in income: The median income for black households was about $28,000 less than for their white counterparts in 2017. While the white median household income reached a new high in 2017, the black median was still below its peak in 2000.

Disparities persist in unemployment: Black unemployment is far higher than the white unemployment rate. Black unemployment peaked at 16.8% after the Great Recession, then fell to 7.7% at the end of the Obama Administration and 6.2% in May (about 2x the white rate).

Today is the 55th anniversary of the #CivilRightsAct. More than half a century since the civil rights movement, racial economic disparities persist. Evidence shows gaps in measures of economic well-being, such as unemployment, income, poverty, homeownership and econ mobility. pic.twitter.com/ic5wDdsgh2
